@ArthurCDent a lot of people have trouble with that and think that you if you believe we should continue to build frameworks, you can't, in the same breath eye them with mistrust.  you have to worship and adore them as products of a particular human genius. "i'll fight you, sir!", etc.

@ArthurCDent in Gray's case, the idea that we are kind of lost in a world we don't really understand and build frameworks to navigate that coexists with the ideas that we should both continue to do so (because it works) and mistrust our love of them because they're frameworks and contingent.

@ArthurCDent didn't mean you, btw. just that online discourse "flattens" every position into simple binaries - for/against, good/bad, etc. applies both to people i think are saying something smart and those i think are irredeemably dumb. exceot JBP, obviously. exception that proves the rule

@ArthurCDent yeah. i don't think that's in dispute by anyone, really, but i find him - and others - an often insightful prophylactic against the assumption that a thing generalises just because it works contingently in a society or circumstance. i'm amenable to life as processes and systems.

@ArthurCDent the broad brush problem. x says y, therefore he means y about *everything* is one thing i've noticed more and more about online discourse. i'm glad i read a lot of primary work before the internet and got in the habit, because if i'd been introduced to it online i'd not bother.

@ArthurCDent but caveat lector, i'm drawing on my own conclusions from reading him a long while back, which are obviously inflected by being mine. my sense is that i always found him interesting, often surprising, and equally often funny. he's helped by being a very good writer, too.

@ArthurCDent iirc, he treats "religion" as a placeholder for the need to organise in a way that makes us feel in control. hence, "the inevitability of progress" under technology, capital, or some other magic ingredient is a "continuation of religion" etc. and takes on similar attributes.

@JamieWoodhouse @derekberes @matthewremski @JulianMWalker Hope that makes sense. As I said, Twitter isn't much use for actual discussion.

@JamieWoodhouse @derekberes @matthewremski @JulianMWalker Be vegetarian or vegan by all means. I have. We should limit harm where we can. But it's not a panacea. And a lot of people who advocate it professionally - the self-appointed gurus - take it as a credential. There are many ways of harm reduction. Credentials aren't one.

@JamieWoodhouse @derekberes @matthewremski @JulianMWalker For example, there's growing evidence that sentience extends to plants. Big argument in the Buddhist community about "all sentient beings". The consensus is basically the Mahayana/ Śrāvakayāna split. If you're only interested in your own purity you select what's worth compassion.

@JamieWoodhouse @derekberes @matthewremski @JulianMWalker Twitter is bad for nuance and conversation. "Personal preference" just means that there's some part of the selection of things worthy of compassion that we do solely based on how it makes us feel. And how we feel is often influenced by things other than compassion.
@JamieWoodhouse @derekberes @matthewremski @JulianMWalker YMMV, of course

@JamieWoodhouse @derekberes @matthewremski @JulianMWalker Coming back to the conspirituality point, diet selection of any type is so often a function of purity claims, reality aversion, and credential markers, that it makes sense to use it as a heuristic.

@JamieWoodhouse @derekberes @matthewremski @JulianMWalker In other words, if a person's diet was actually based on compassion rather than self aggrandisement, that compassion would be reflected in other parts of their life. And, conversely, if it wasn't, they'd be prone to thinking their obligations were done when they ate differently.

@JamieWoodhouse @derekberes @matthewremski @JulianMWalker Well, the exact same claim applies to clothing, electronic goods, cars, houses, and so on. I think the point he was making was that reifying some behaviour over others had more to do with personal preference than compassion. He was vegetarian, at the time, fwiw.
@beccalew This is such an inevitable picture.

@JamieWoodhouse @derekberes @matthewremski @JulianMWalker Joking aside, his central objection, apart from the "lung disease" thing, was that an obsession with avoiding some part of the kāmadhātu negated engaging with reality. That struck me harder. What @derekberes and @JulianMWalker probably mean by purity politics.

@JamieWoodhouse @derekberes @matthewremski @JulianMWalker I should clarify that he's in no way responsible for the fact that I went straight to whisky. I've always been an extremely bad student. But, arguably, I'm a much, much better person.

@JamieWoodhouse @derekberes @matthewremski @JulianMWalker The ethical argument is where he arguably took the most offence, on the grounds that you can't parse your diet and think you're doing less harm. The problems aren't solved by selective attention.

@JamieWoodhouse @derekberes @matthewremski @JulianMWalker I did :)

Thanks

@derekberes @JamieWoodhouse @matthewremski @JulianMWalker Same. Vegan for 2, vegetarian for 10. Also helpful for my sense of superiority.
RT @kenklippenstein: Per State Department travel advisory re FIFA World Cup in Qatar: “If a U.S. citizen is a victim of sexual assault in Q…
RT @restofworld: Imagine if everything in your home came from just one person: the food you eat, the clothes you wear, the fuel you fill in…

@ThatDaveBowden "88% of the human beings in Qatar are paid to make the lives of 12% comfortable. Granted, they're not paid very much, have no political rights, and are effectively at the mercy of their 'owners' but wouldn't you say that's a triumph for capitalism? Wouldn't you? Huh?"

@BenjySarlin @kenklippenstein The gamification of elections is infantile. Most people, whatever their nominal affiliation, are acutely aware that they're marginalised by capital. The issues aren't things like "Oz vs Fetterman", but things like "who should be able to determine the future of the world."

"The Crow Road" is still one of the best novels about human beings I know of and "The Bridge" is a work of art. I'm not sure I'm ready for either yet, but I'm happy that I can scroll through a list of his work and feel grateful, rather than upset. (I bought both. Holding thumbs.)

So here's a metric. Iain Banks died in 2013. I'd religiously followed his publishing schedule: a new book every year. When he announced he was dying, I wept. Today I finished Raw Spirit on audio. First time since then I've opened a book. My recovery time is 9 years, apparently.
